I'm a Swiss citizen and also an economist. About 75% of what the professor 
says is just untrue and not precise enough. He clearly wasn't prepared or 
doesn't know Switzerland at all. Worst, his academic abilities might be 
manipulated by his political views. The "minimum revenue" he speaks about 
hasn't been voted yet and will surely be refused. The minimum wage was 
refused in 2014 by 76.3% of the population. The 1/12 initiative (created by 
the Socialists) was refused by 66% of the population in 2013. The Gini 
coefficient (calculating the inequality within a society) of Switzerland is 
one of the lowest in the world, much lower than many european countries led 
by left-wing parties (like France). The median wage in Switzerland 
(calculated in PPP) is one of the highest in the World and the purchasing 
power of the middle class hasn't been decreasing, quite the opposite. Plus, 
if the banking/finance sector is important to our economy, it is still only 
about 5% of our GDP. So please, forget about this world cliché of 
Switzerland being nothing but a big safe. 

We have our problems, no doubt about it. But please, if you want to do a 
realistic analysis of a country, at least try to rely on facts and not 
ideology and/or anecdotes. 
I have the greatest respect for the USA, a country I've lived in and 
appreciate a lot. I also have a lot of respect for many american 
universities, including the University of Massachusetts. This is why I'm a 
little bit disappointed by the "analysis" of this professor who, I hope, 
knows better about his country than about mine. 

Plus David, where did you see a 30 USD burger? I knew that restaurants in 
Zurich are expensive but not 10 times more expensive than in the rest of 
the country... :)﻿

+Silvan Wespi *:* *"In the end, if they have 100million or a billion 
doesn't make any difference to the people in their daily life."*
You are probably correct.  Many factors contribute to this sort of 
fatalism, and it is hard to motivate complacent people to change the way 
they live.  In the US, we aren't doing so well, and its hard to argue that 
people are unmotivated to change simply because they are complacent.  A 
deeper understanding of what is going on, would require models with enough 
explanatory power that they will be capable of describing the similar lack 
of action in both the US and Switzerland, as well as many other countries 
that would included developing and undeveloped nations. 

With that in mind, there is one "model"/"perspective" that I only rarely 
see that is capable of providing a different perspective on how problematic 
inequality can be.  Economic systems are dynamic, and the change our 
society demands is not simply *"growth"*, but really the *accelerated 
"growth of growth."*  This sort of growing growth is what investors bet 
their money on, and so businesses that *ONLY* profit will be considered 
failures if there profit margin lacks continual and accelerate growth. 

The point is that our society creates wealth at a constantly increasing 
rate, and when inequality gets worse, this means that average people are 
working more to produce what is essentially *"excess wealth"* that they 
never see.  It is the constant production and growth of this *excess wealth* 
that has an immediate and obvious impact on every person with a job: we are 
working more than we need to in order to run our society. 

In the US, real wages have been fairly stagnant for the past 40 years, even 
though productivity continued to grow during that entire time.  You can see 
it most strikingly in data like this,
https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Productivity_and_Real_Median_Family_Income_Growth_1947-2009.png 
.

The plot shows the change in "real median family income" over time, from 
1947 to 2011.  This "change" includes the "growing growth" that I told you 
about, but can also include periods of "no growth" and of decline.  On the 
vertical-axis, "100%" refers to their being no change in income from some 
arbitrarily chosen point in the late 60's or early 70's. The result is that 
our income is less than 25% larger than this arbitrary reference point from 
40 years ago. 

What makes this arbitrary point interesting is that it represents the point 
when real wages become disconnected from the real growth in our 
productivity.  Since this time, productivity has *tripled*, while we only 
experienced 1/10th of that growth in our income. 

The "model"/"perspective" that I spoke of earlier, that is capable of 
illustrating the real and immediate every day impact of inequality is that 
the degree to which we overwork may be enough that everyone could work 
"part-time" (less than 25 hours), while maintaining their current standard 
of living.  Everyone keeps the wealth and property they currently own, but 
that excess wealth goes to us who can choose to either work less than they 
currently do while maintaining their current standard of living, or they 
can still work less than they currently do, and increase their standard of 
living by working the new "overtime" which is the current "full-time." 

In the US, this chart *implies* that our standard 40 hour work week (true 
avg 42 hours in 2013) could, on average be decreased to 1/3rd that amount 
(about 13 hours) every week, while getting the same paycheck every week. 
In Switzerland, the average hours worked per week is 35 hours (average 
$50,000/yr), and is likely a little bit less than it has been in the past, 
if it follows the trend of most other progressive countries.  The amount is 
still small, but is much more than the change for Americans which has been 
effectively stagnant for about 30 years. 

The System sucks and we are wasting our lives away.  We can do better than 
this.

The "American Right" doesn't say that minimum wage legislation "makes items 
expensive" for consumers; to the extent that the American Right has any 
economic policy, it simply recognizes that minimum wage legislation (like 
any form of price control) simply distorts the affected markets by making 
it more costly to hire new employees, and requiring the dismissal those 
already hired whose productivity can't sustain their newly mandated wage 
levels. The displaced workers must move elsewhere, pushing wages in these 
(often labor-intensive) businesses, even more downward, and the new minimum 
wage levels less affordable to employers.

All in all, ask yourself, if low wages could be corrected without any 
negative consequences simply by legislation, why don't legislators pass a 
"minimum wage" of a million dollars (Euros, Yen, Francs, Rubles...) a 
month, and then everybody will be a millionaire!

The minimum wage law IS a wealth transfer mechanism, but NOT between 
employers and employees, but between employees who productivity doesn't 
fulfill the wage requirement, and hence must be dismissed (thus earning a 
wage of zero) and more skilled, experienced, and ambitious employees who 
can still be kept on profitably while paying them by the new standard.﻿

doesn't tell the whole picture. I think Switzerland has struck a nice 
balance between employee protection and job mobility. Combined with low 
unemployment and good social protection for those who 'are of the loop' for 
good, the job market even for low end jobs is never swamped. This means 
that there's almost always opportunities for employees to get a better job 
if their company doesn't pay enough. So social insurances combined with a

I believe that you are quite misinformed with regards to Switzerland. I am 
not Swiss but I visited that country many, many times as y family lives 
there and I absolutely love it every time I go. I am yet to come across a 
$30 cheeseburger so I am not quite sure where you paid that amount. As for 
food quality, I can assure you that no country in the world comes remotely 
close to Switzerland with regards to quality control. That is the only 
country in the world where I would consider consuming a fast food product 
because I know how stringent tests you have to pass before you are even 
allowed to sell the product in Switzerland, burgers including. Swiss tap 
water is something that the rest of the world can only dream about, I am 
subjected to much laughter from my family when they see me drink it by the 
gallon every time I go to visit :-). Basic needs in Switzerland are 
affordable to everybody, the more luxurious the product is the more it is 
going to cost you which makes every sense in the world. Housing is quite 
expensive but then again come to Paris or London and let me know how much 
that is going to cost you over here. Swiss public transport in its current 
state is roughly where the rest of the Europe will be in say 20-30 years 
time and it is easily affordable. You can set your wrist watch using their 
bus service, trust me on this one. I can assure you that I am not employed 
by Swiss tourist board advertising the country :-) but I was a bit taken 
aback by your talk about Switzerland being THAT expensive. As someone who 
visits the country once or twice every year I don't find it extraordinarily 
expensive at all. Switzerland is the closest to democracy as I have ever 
seen in my life, they vote on everything so you really do get the feeling 
that you as a citizen matter. It's only a small country so it is 
notoriously difficult to get residence permit but who can blame them, take 
a look at the rest of the Europe and try to convince me that mass 
emigration works. A word of warning though. You can learn to fly the plane, 
become Formula 1 pilot and so on but you will never learn Swiss German, 
ever.﻿

Sorry, but this Mr. Wolff has no clue whatsoever about the Swiss economy. 
He just mixes myths and stereotypes with his simplicistic textbook 
ideology, and that's his "analysis". He sounds like a primary-school pupil 
snobbishly convinced that his freshly acquired small knowledge is already 
enough to explain the world to everyone. It starts with the claim of a huge 
income gap which he would have actually to recant when the moderator 
teaches him that Swiss wages even for the lowest-paid jobs are on a level 
unheard of anywhere else. It is also not true that the wealthiest Swiss are 
bankers. There is not a single banker among the 50 wealthiest Swiss 
residents! Bank ownership is very diversified. Switzerland is in fact 
expensive because of the earnings of its export industry selling a lot of 
high-margin products like luxury watches or sophisticated pharmaceuticals 
among other things. The high wages of workers in these industries allow 
also for the internal economy to pay higher wages/ask higher prices. The 
cost of the workers wages make up in fact 70-80% of the revenues in the 
majority of Swiss businesses! So they ARE the main factor determining the 
price! If a business cannot pay their workers a certain wage, the service 
simply cannot exist, as Switzerland has de facto full employment. If that 
service appears to be vital for the economy and society, they simply 
automatically have to raise the wages and with them the prices in order to 
attract enough manpower. Another factor is the densely populated space in a 
very mountainous terrain which makes real estate rare and expensive, 
similar to Japan. Mr. Wolff seems to still think in the patterns of Karl 
Marx and the 19th century industrial age when he tries to give equal 
significance to material, energy etc. Welcome to the service economy and 
the 21st century! Other plain factual mistakes by Mr. Wolff: Switzerland is 
NOT in the EU. The initiative on unconditional minimum income has NOT been 
voted on yet. There has been recently a vote on a (much less extreme) 
official minimum wage for workers, and it has achieved merely 23% of 
Yes-votes. So the vote on unconditional minimum income will be most 
probably below 20% Yes, not the "nearly 50%" Mr. Wolff seemed to have 
dreamed about.    ﻿

Very interesting conversation; Switzerland by any means is a prosperous 
country and that is because it is a very well run country; the politicians 
generally know what to do and the swiss are responsive to that. Secondly, 
Switzerland has a huge current-account surplus with the rest of the world, 
because of banking but also because it goes out of its way to attract 
foreign companies through fiscal incentives; this in turn creates the 
lowest unemployment rate in Europe (c.4%), which creates demand for more 
labour (hence more immigration) and hence the very high wages (a 
supermarket employee can earn 4000SF a month which is a lot of money).
Wages are high but services are also expensive: health services are of a 
high quality but expensive, people discount a lot for social security and 
retirement age;  the average swiss home is 50 sq m large, women go on 
average 6x a year to the hairdresser and basic services like going to a 
restaurant are not cheap. Part of this problem is the exchange rate of the 
swiss franc to major currencies, which does not make it cheap. Something 
most foreigners don´t know also is that the consumer in Switzerland gets a 
very bad deal as most companies try to fleece the swiss consumer because 
they can afford it: a BMW may be the same price in Germany, France or Italy 
but it can be 30% more expensive in Switzerland. The government here fails 
miserably the consumer because the central government has transfered a lot 
of power to the cantons and the cantons cannot get together in an efficient 
way to solve this problem. Hence the huge numbers of swiss citizens who 
cross the borders to shop in France, Italy and Germany where everything is 
cheaper.
All in all Switzerland offers some of the highest standards of living in 
the world as well as quality of life (eg Zurich is often considered the 
best city to live in the world). It is not all bad but Switzerland is a 
very interesting study-case for anyone interested in economics.﻿
